item.title: Chris Rodgers
item.description: @computingnature @jperkel @bleds22e Totally agree! I‚Äôm a big advocate for sharing. But I think being too maximalist and mandatory about it makes people feel like it‚Äôs an imposition or that they‚Äôre not qualified. Any amount is better than nothing

item.title: Total Internal Reflection
item.description: New posting! This one is about the number of unpaid hours in #academia, an insight that's come from the realisation of how much time I'm still committing despite now (currently) being unemployed. To what extent is academic research sustained by the massive expenditure of unpaid labour? How much unpaid overtime do you think you're clocking? Let's lift the lid...https://totalinternalreflectionblog.com/2023/06/29/pro-bono-a-riff-on-unpaid-labour-in-academia/

item.title: Guy Rohkin
item.description: Wanted to throw out an intro here~I'm Guy, one of the founders of https://www.scifind.net/, an expert network where scientists go to troubleshoot experimental problems. It's an #openaccess tacit knowledge database (a "lab-rary" üòÖ) of tips, negative results, optimizations, discussions, methods (stuff that's not in publication really helps get your experiments to work!) Show some love ‚ù§Ô∏è, take a look, make a post and help out :D #openscience #introduction #ScienceMastodon #biology #synbio #science

item.title: Qasim Rashid, Esq.
item.description: Affirmative action was never about admitting unqualified Black kids. It was always about ensuring qualified Black kids could also get accepted despite a world of systemic racism.The ‚Äúunqualified admission‚Äù you‚Äôre thinking of are legacy students‚Äîlike how Kavanaugh got into Yale, or how George W. got into yale, or how Kushner got into Harvard.Every GOP accusation is a confession, and this is no exception.

item.title: CMDR Yojimbosan UTC+(12|13)
item.description:
From https://isc.sans.edu/diary/Geolocating+IPs+is+harder+than+you+think/29834
...
This is one reason why Google recently started using "google.com/maps" for its "Google Maps." Users will gladly give Google Maps access to their location. After all, the map needs to know where you are to give directions. But by using "google.com/maps" instead of "maps.google.com," all "google.com" properties now have access to the user's location after the user gave access to the location on google.com/maps.

item.title: JB Emmons
item.description: Yesterday, Donald #Trump posted screenshots on his #TruthSocial account that featured the DC home address for Barack #Obama.In response, a #Jan6 participant boosted Trump's post, added "See you in hell, Podesta's and Obama's!" to his own Telegram, and then drove right over to the Obamas' home.He was arrested nearby, with 2 firearms, 400 rounds, and a machete found in his van.#USpolhttps://www.nbcnews.com/politics/justice-department/jan-6-defendant-arrested-obamas-home-guns-400-rounds-ammunition-van-rcna92094

item.title: Renee DiResta
item.description: ‚ÄúMy follower count is dropping! I‚Äôm being censored!‚Äù Lol no your mid content just resulted in unfollows bc people don‚Äôt want to accidentally consume you as part of their 600 posts.

item.title: Ashley Juavinett
item.description:
The ability to define and target cell types right now is absolutely incredible -- neuroscientists are answering questions that were totally intractable a decade ago.I spoke with several leaders in this effort in my latest for Simons Global Brain!
https://www.simonsfoundation.org/2022/11/22/crossing-the-divide-defining-neurons-by-both-genes-and-function/

item.title: Jonas Wietek :vibing:

‚ô° Genetically encoded

item.title: Sarah Brown
item.description: Dear Twitter people. Lots of us were once Twitter people too. This place will not spoon-feed you. Passive participation doesn‚Äôt work here. This is a very active and buzzing place, but unless you FOLLOW people and INTERACT, it will pass you by.Follow people. Lots of them. You can always remove them later. But really, follow early, follow often.
